metadata.case_name: Ruler of Baster State v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant was the Ruler of the State of Baster.
Appellant executed an Instrument of Accession to the Dominion of India on August 14, 1947.
Appellant entered into a Stand Still Agreement with the Dominion of India.

On December 15, 1947, appellant entered into a Merger Agreement with the Government of India, ceding the State of Baster to be integrated with the Central Provinces and Berar as part of Madhya Pradesh.
Governments of India came to have exclusive and plenary authority, jurisdiction and powers over Baster State with effect from January 1, 1948.
Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (MP Act 1 of 1951) received assent of President on January 22, 1951.
Appellant filed petition under Arts. 226 and 227 in Nagpur High Court (Misc. Petn. No. 1231 of 1951) regarding villages in Schedules A and B.
Nagpur High Court dismissed appellant's petition on October 16, 1952, and certified under Art. 132(1) substantial question of law.
Villages in Schedules A and B were exempt from payment of rent or tax (maufi lands).
Bhandar villages had been assessed to land revenue, as per documents on record.
Villages in Schedules A and B (except Bhandar) not recognized as private property of appellant by Government of India as per Merger Agreement.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is a proprietor within the meaning of that expression in the Act.
Whether the villages in question came within the definition of the word mahal contained in the Act.
Whether the Act could defeat the rights of the appellant guaranteed under Art. 3 of the Merger Agreement.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant was still a Sovereign Ruler and absolute owner of the villages in Schedules A and B; rights recognized and guaranteed under agreements with Government of India; provisions of the Act did not apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 6 of Instrument of Accession; first paragraph of Art. 3 of Merger Agreement

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of the Act did not apply to a Ruler or to the private property of a Ruler which was not assessed to land revenue.
Appellant not a maufidar as term confined to grantee from State or Ruler.
Appellant as Ruler under Art. 366(22) did not come within expression ex-Ruler in definition of proprietor.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 366(22) of Constitution; s. 2(m) of the Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Villages not assessed to land revenue, hence not mahals.

respondent_arguments.text: Villages had been assessed to land revenue.

court_reasoning.text: Disputes arising out of Merger Agreement or Instrument of Accession beyond competence of courts by virtue of Art. 363(1); High Court rightly decided against appellant.
Appellant factually an ex-Ruler after ceding State; Art. 366(22) recognition as Ruler only for constitutional purposes like privy purse under Art. 291, not for the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in Art. 366(22) requires recognition as Ruler outside Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant as ex-Ruler specifically included in definition of proprietor under s. 2(m); also a maufidar as holder of rent-free land, not necessarily grantee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Maufidar includes holder of land exempt from rent/tax.

court_reasoning.text: No material that appellant as maufidar lacked right to recover rent/revenue per wajib-ul-arz; burden on appellant not discharged; argument raised first time in Supreme Court.
No evidence villages not assessed to land revenue; Bhandar villages assessed per records; question of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on appellant; evidence shows assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Other villages not recognized as private property per Merger Agreement, petition not maintainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No recognition by Government of India.

holdings.text: Appellant is an ex-Ruler and maufidar, hence proprietor under s. 2(m) of the Act.
Villages fall within definition of mahal under s. 2(j) of the Act.
Art. 363(1) bars enquiry into disputes under Merger Agreement or Instrument of Accession.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Bar on judicial review of accession/merger agreements; definition of Ruler; writ jurisdiction

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (Act 1 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of proprietary rights; definitions of proprietor (includes ex-Ruler, maufidar) and mahal

statutes_cited.name: Instrument of Accession
statutes_cited.relevance: Guarantees to Ruler; barred by Art. 363

statutes_cited.name: Merger Agreement
statutes_cited.relevance: Cession of State; private property recognition; barred by Art. 363

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Nagpur High Court's dismissal of the petition under Arts. 226 and 227, holding appellant as ex-Ruler and maufidar hence proprietor, villages as mahals under the Act, and disputes under agreements barred by Art. 363.

key_quotes.text: "It seems clear to us, however, that in view of the provisions of Art. 363(1) of the Constitution any dispute arising out of the Merger Agreement or the Instrument of Accession is beyond the competence of the courts to enquire into."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes bar on judicial review of agreements

key_quotes.text: "There is nothing in the provisions of Art. 366(22) which requires a court to recognise such a person as a Ruler for purposes outside the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits definition of Ruler to constitutional purposes

key_quotes.text: "A maufidar could be a person who was the holder of land which was exempted from the payment of rent or tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Broadens interpretation of maufidar to include appellant
